measured_by: DDM drift-rate weights on self payoff (w_self) and other payoff (w_other)
justification: The text states that Hutcherson et al. (2015) "use a drift function = w_self ($ self) + w_other ($ other) to model social preferences: allocating money between oneself and another," indicating that the DDM weight parameters serve as the measurement of the social-preference construct.

measured_by: DDM drift-rate weights on health (w_health) and taste (w_taste) attributes
justification: It notes that Enax et al. (2016) "used a drift function = w_health (health) + w_taste (taste) to model food choice, weighing health considerations against taste," showing that the relative drift-rate weights capture the construct of health-versus-taste weighting in food decisions.
construct: food choice trade-off / health vs. taste considerations

measured_by: DDM drift-rate weights on amount (w_amount) and time delay (w_delay)
justification: The article explains that Amasino et al. (2019) "used a drift function = w_amount (amount) + w_delay (delay) to model intertemporal choices, weighing the amount of money against the time to receive it," indicating these drift weights operationalize the amount-delay trade-off construct.
